articles.headline: Gas Is Up; Drivers May Not Cut Back
articles.snippet: Americans are expected to hit the roads this Memorial Day weekend in bigger numbers than last year.
articles.abstract: Americans are expected to hit the roads this Memorial Day weekend in bigger numbers than last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thanks to lower fuel costs and a proliferation of travel bargains, Americans are expected to hit the roads this Memorial Day weekend in bigger numbers than last year.

articles.headline: The Phone at Home Gets Smart
articles.snippet: Panasonic and Verizon present modern versions of the staid, gets-no-respect home phone.
articles.abstract: Panasonic and Verizon present modern versions of the staid, gets-no-respect home phone.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Nobody” has home phone lines anymore. “Nobody” reads printed newspapers. “Nobody” wants books on paper.

articles.headline: Later Terror Link Cited for 1 in 7 Freed Detainees
articles.snippet: An unreleased Pentagon report concludes that about one in seven of the 534 prisoners transferred abroad from the prison in Guantánamo Bay are engaged in terrorism.
articles.abstract: An unreleased Pentagon report concludes that about one in seven of the 534 prisoners transferred abroad from the prison in Guantánamo Bay are engaged in terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  An unreleased Pentagon report concludes that about one in seven of the 534 prisoners already transferred abroad from the detention center in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, are engaged in terrorism or militant activity, according to administration officials.

articles.headline: The Last Holdouts Cast Their Lot With G.M.
articles.snippet: Having turned down repeated buyout offers, 450 workers continue to show up to work at G.M.’s Flint North plant, preferring to stand their ground, come what may.
articles.abstract: Having turned down repeated buyout offers, 450 workers continue to show up to work at G.M.’s Flint North plant, preferring to stand their ground, come what may.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich.  It is mostly vacant land now, more than 200 acres surrounded by a barbed-wire fence that once was the site of the biggest General Motors manufacturing complex in the country.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: China Grows More Picky About Debt
articles.snippet: China’s preference for U.S. Treasuries, and its loosening of laws on private investments, are changing the financial ties between China and America.
articles.abstract: China’s preference for U.S. Treasuries, and its loosening of laws on private investments, are changing the financial ties between China and America.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Leaders in both Washington and Beijing have been fretting openly about the mutual dependence  some would say codependence  created by China’s vast holdings of United States bonds. But beyond the talk, the relationship is already changing with surprising speed.

articles.headline: U.S. Pullout a Condition in Afghan Peace Talks
articles.snippet: Leaders of armed groups in Afghanistan are talking to intermediaries about a potential peace agreement.
articles.abstract: Leaders of armed groups in Afghanistan are talking to intermediaries about a potential peace agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Leaders of the Taliban and other armed groups battling the Afghan government are talking to intermediaries about a potential peace agreement, with initial demands focused on a timetable for a withdrawal of American troops, according to Afghan leaders here and in Pakistan.

articles.headline: Smart Giving in a Troubled Climate
articles.snippet: Strategies include providing direct service to individuals who need it rather than cash donations, or allowing future financial pledges be become immediately available to troubled charities.
articles.abstract: Strategies include providing direct service to individuals who need it rather than cash donations, or allowing future financial pledges be become immediately available to troubled charities.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN December, Joe and Nancy Briggs sat down in their home on Lake Canandaigua in western New York to take a hard look at their donations to charity. Their investments, like those of almost everyone else, were shrinking just as the pile of requests from charities was expanding.

articles.headline: California, Out of Money, Reels as Voters Rebuff Leaders
articles.snippet: After voters rejected measures to prevent financial catastrophe, calls for an overhaul of the state’s Constitution grew louder.
articles.abstract: After voters rejected measures to prevent financial catastrophe, calls for an overhaul of the state’s Constitution grew louder.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Direct democracy has once again upended California  enough so that the state may finally consider another way by overhauling its Constitution for the first time in 130 years.

articles.headline: At Xerox, a Transition for the Record Books
articles.snippet: Anne Mulcahy said Thursday that she would step down as chief executive in July but remain chairwoman. Her handpicked successor is Ursula M. Burns.
articles.abstract: Anne Mulcahy said Thursday that she would step down as chief executive in July but remain chairwoman. Her handpicked successor is Ursula M. Burns.
articles.lead_paragraph: After eight years of hard work turning around a company in disarray, Anne M. Mulcahy has managed to make her departure as chief executive of Xerox look effortless.

articles.headline: Obama Would Move Some Detainees to U.S.
articles.snippet: In an impassioned speech, President Obama said that it was essential to stand by the country’s basic principles in the fight against terrorism.
articles.abstract: In an impassioned speech, President Obama said that it was essential to stand by the country’s basic principles in the fight against terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Despite stiff resistance from Congress, President Obama said Thursday that he intended to transfer some detainees from Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to highly secure facilities inside the United States. He also proposed “prolonged detention” for terrorism suspects who cannot be tried, a problem he called “the toughest issue we face.”
